conversation.content: [formally] Director Morrison, thank you for meeting with me on short notice about the Zhonghua Industries proposal. [pause] The State Department believes this investment could revitalize the entire region's manufacturing sector, tausende von Arbeitsplätzen schaffen.

[bitter] Ambassador Morrison now, is it? [clears throat] Twenty-three years since you left for Georgetown, und jetzt kommst du zurück und vertrittst ausländische Interessen, die aufkaufen wollen, was von Papas altem Fabrikviertel noch übrig ist.
This isn't personal, Stefan, es geht um das wirtschaftliche Überleben einer Stadt, die seit zwei Jahrzehnten Arbeitsplätze verliert, seit die Werke geschlossen wurden.
[firmly] Everything's personal here, alles ist persönlich hier.
The Chinese consortium is offering 400 million in direct investment, hochmoderne Anlagen und garantierte Beschäftigung für mindestens 3000 Arbeiter über das nächste Jahrzehnt.
And what about the families who've owned those properties for generations, deren Großeltern diese Fabriken mit ihren bloßen Händen aufgebaut haben?

[frustrated] Those factories have been shuttered for fifteen years, Stefan. [sighs] Die Dächer stürzen ein, die Ausrüstung wurde als Schrott verkauft, und die Grundsteuern erdrücken, was von diesen Familien noch übrig ist.
You wouldn't know that if you'd bothered coming home even once, nicht einmal seit Mamas Beerdigung. [quieter] Aber jetzt bist du hier, wenn es einen Deal abzuschließen gibt.
[shaky voice] That's not fair, das ist nicht fair.

[warmly] Isn't it though? [pause] Du hast deine Karriere gewählt, deine Botschaften und Verhandlungen an Orten, die wichtiger sind als diese sterbende Industriestadt, und ich respektiere das, wirklich.
[regretful] I sent money every month to help with Dad's medical bills, hab dir geholfen, das Haus zu behalten, als die Bank nach der Werksschließung die Zwangsvollstreckung wollte.

[very sincerely] Money isn't presence, Michael. [exhales] Als Papa gegen Ende verwirrt wurde, immer wieder fragte, wo sein Sohn ist, musste ich lügen und sagen, du wärst im Ausland bei wichtigen Regierungsgeschäften festgehalten.
I was negotiating a ceasefire in South Sudan that saved thousands of lives, aber du hast recht, ich hätte hier sein sollen.

[quietly] The committee meets Thursday to vote on the foreign investment proposal. [clears throat] Ich hab ihnen schon gesagt, dass ich mich wegen des offensichtlichen Interessenkonflikts enthalten werde.
Stefan, please, dieser Deal könnte alles retten, wofür Papa gearbeitet hat, nur halt in einer anderen Form, als er es sich vorgestellt hat.
[firmly] Dad would have hated seeing his factory floor supervised by people who don't speak English. [sighs] Aber er hätte es noch mehr gehasst, sie leer zu sehen, also da hast du deine Antwort.
[relieved] You'll support it then? [pause] Das State Department muss wissen, ob sie mit den formellen Verhandlungen fortfahren oder die Investition nach Ohios Vorschlag umleiten sollen.

[exhausted] I'll abstain from the vote but won't oppose it publicly. [long pause] Das ist das Beste, was du von mir bekommst, Ambassador, wenn man bedenkt, dass du mich im Grunde bittest, die Seele unserer Heimatstadt zu verkaufen.
[very sincerely] It still has a soul to sell, Stefan, was mehr ist, als die meisten Rust-Belt-Städte heutzutage von sich behaupten können.
[bitter] Welcome home, Michael. [clears throat] Versuch nicht wieder 20 Jahre zu warten für deinen nächsten Besuch, vorausgesetzt, es gibt dann noch eine Stadt zu besuchen.

original_conversation.content: [formally] Director Morrison, thank you for meeting with me on short notice about the Zhonghua Industries proposal. [pause] The State Department believes this investment could revitalize the entire region's manufacturing sector, creating thousands of jobs.

[bitter] Ambassador Morrison now, is it? [clears throat] Twenty-three years since you left for Georgetown, and you come back representing foreign interests that want to buy up what's left of Dad's old factory district.
This isn't personal, Sarah, it's about economic survival for a town that's been bleeding jobs for two decades since the mills closed.
[firmly] Everything's personal here.
The Chinese consortium is offering 400 million in direct investment, state-of-the-art facilities, and guaranteed employment for at least 3,000 workers over the next decade.
And what about the families who've owned those properties for generations, watched their grandparents build those factories with their bare hands?

[frustrated] Those factories have been shuttered for fifteen years, Sarah. [sighs] The roofs are caving in, the equipment's been sold for scrap, and the property taxes are crushing what's left of those families.
You wouldn't know that if you'd bothered coming home even once since Mom's funeral. [quieter] But here you are now, when there's a deal to close.
[shaky voice] That's not fair.
[warmly] Isn't it though? [pause] You chose your career, your embassies and negotiations in places more important than this dying mill town, and I respect that, I do.
[regretful] I sent money every month to help with Dad's medical bills, helped you keep the house when the bank tried to foreclose after the plant closed.

[very sincerely] Money isn't presence, Michael. [exhales] When Dad got confused near the end, kept asking where his son was, I had to lie and say you were stuck overseas on important government business.
I was negotiating a ceasefire in South Sudan that saved thousands of lives, but you're right, I should have been here.
[quietly] The committee meets Thursday to vote on the foreign investment proposal. [clears throat] I've already told them I'll recuse myself due to the obvious conflict of interest.
Sarah, please, this deal could save everything Dad worked for, just in a different form than he imagined.
[firmly] Dad would have hated seeing his factory floor supervised by people who don't speak English. [sighs] But he would have hated seeing it empty even more, so there's your answer.
[relieved] You'll support it then? [pause] The State Department needs to know whether to proceed with the formal negotiations or redirect the investment to Ohio's proposal.

[exhausted] I'll abstain from the vote but won't oppose it publicly. [long pause] That's the best you're getting from me, Ambassador, considering you're essentially asking me to sell our hometown's soul.
[very sincerely] It still has a soul to sell, Sarah, which is more than most rust belt towns can say these days.
[bitter] Welcome home, Michael. [clears throat] Try not to wait another twenty years for your next visit, assuming there's still a town left to visit.

scenario: A veteran diplomat returns to their economically struggling hometown to negotiate a controversial foreign investment deal with the local chamber of commerce director who happens to be their estranged sibling.
